captions.text:
This episode of Dnews was proudly made possible
by the all-new 2015 Subaru Legacy. It’s
not just a sedan - it’s a Subaru.

Switzerland has become a hotspot for suicide
tourism - but what does that mean? And how
exactly does it work?

Hey guys, Tara here for Dnews - and you’ve
probably heard of the term “assisted suicide”

at some point. It’s a legal form of suicide,
that’s performed with the help of medical

professionals. Most places in the world have
banned it, for ethical or religious reasons

- but there is one country where assisted
suicide is perfectly legal, and that’s Switzerland.

Currently, Switzerland has 6 different right-to-die
organizations, 4 of which willingly accept
patients who live outside the country.

One of those organizations, is called “Dignitas
- to live with dignity, to die with dignity.”

It was founded in 1998, and since then, it’s
helped assist in the suicides of over 1,000

people in Zurich. But as far as assisted suicide
goes, it’s relatively new - the practice
has been legal in Switzerland since 1942.

Interestingly, there are a few states in the
US that do legally allow physician-assisted

suicide - including Oregon, Washington, Vermont,
and New Mexico - but Switzerland is unique,

because it’s one of the few countries with
no national laws against it. As such, it’s

created something of a “suicide tourism”
industry, where people travel from all over

the world, with the intent of ending their
life.

Of course, not just anybody can choose to
do this. All patients undergo a thorough psychiatric

evaluation, to make sure they’re of sound
mind - but they also have to have a legitimate

medical reason for wanting to do it. And a
recent study published in the British Journal

of Medicine, aims to find out exactly who
is partaking in suicide tourism - and why.

A team of researchers combed through databases
of information from the Institute of Legal

Medicine in Zurich, and looked at 611 cases
of assisted suicide between 2008 and 2012,
involving people from outside countries.

The average age of someone seeking assisted
suicide, was 69 years old - ranging from 23

all the way up to 97. And women, they found,
were 40% more likely to choose assisted suicide,

than men. The 611 cases also included people
from 31 different countries - yet almost two-thirds

of the patients came from either Germany or
the UK.

So why were they seeking suicide? Well, the
laws in the US state that you must have a

terminal illness, with a prognosis of less
than 6 months left to live. But it’s not

like that in Switzerland. Certain organizations
- like Dignitas - do only work with terminally

ill patients. But the actual Swiss laws, say
you just have prove that you’re not doing

it for “selfish” reasons, you’re doing
it to “relieve suffering” - whether that’s
physical, mental, or both.

In this study, the most common reason for
someone seeking suicide, were neurological

diseases - like paralysis, Parkinson’s,
motor neuron disease, and multiple sclerosis.

Those accounted for almost half of the total
cases, followed by cancer and rheumatic diseases.
And about 1 in 3 people, had multiple conditions.

Now as foreign a concept as this is for most
of us - if you ignore the religious implications,

there is something that seems wrong about
denying someone the ability to die with dignity,

if they’re truly suffering from an incurable
illness. After all, we administer euthanasia

to our pets when they’re suffering. And
from a moral standpoint, that’s even more
egregious - because animals can’t give consent.

It is worth noting, though, the distinction
between euthanasia and “assisted suicide.”

Euthanasia is administered by someone else
- whereas “assisted suicide” is just that

- assisted. In Switzerland at least, the drug
can only be “prepared” by a doctor - and

the person who’s committing suicide has
to administer the drug themselves.

For most people in Switzerland, that drug
is sodium pentobarbital. It’s typically

used to euthanize animals, but it’s also
been included in some of the lethal injection

cocktails given to inmates here in the US.
When injected in high doses, it effectively

slows down your brain function, almost immediately,
to the point where it stops - and once your
brain stops, eventually so does your heart.

As far as lethal injection cocktails go, it’s
one of the more humane options. But even so,

the topic of assisted suicide is still highly
controversial, and most countries - including

Germany and the UK - aren’t eager to make
it legal, anytime soon.

What are your thoughts on this? Do you think
assisted suicide should be legal, or should

it remain outlawed? Let us know what you think
in the comments below - and as always, thank
you guys for watching!

title: Why Are People Going To Switzerland To Kill Themselves?
